ANNUAL ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE FOR PUBLIC SERVICES

AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES FOR 1961

2.32 p.m.

MAIN ESTIMATES, 1961 (Cont.)


    Head 28-

    The Chairman: The Question is, "That the sum to be allocated for Head 28 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (59) of sub-head 1."

    Hon. Members will recollect that it has been agreed that the debate may range over sub-head 63. It is also on the Political Study Centre. Dr Goh Keng Swee.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I was just about to reply to the three questions raised by the Member for Mountbatten when the recording system unfortunately broke down.

    If I may recapitulate, first, she wanted to know for whom the Political Study Centre is meant; second, what type of instruction goes on; and third, what benefit is derived by the students and the State from these activities.

    On the first question, the Political Study Centre is meant for civil servants, not only those in the Administrative services but also Government employees

Column: 386

in Division II posts who perform duties relating to administrative work of one kind or another. The Centre has also run a series of classes for principals of English primary schools, and some time next year we hope to run similar classes of political instruction for principals of Chinese language schools.

    As regards the content of the courses, as the title suggests, the courses are designed to impart knowledge of political theory, political institutions in general, and Asian political developments in particular.

    Thirdly, as to whether these courses have benefited the students and the State, I would say undoubtedly they have.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, I wonder whether the Minister for Finance would be kind enough to tell us in what way the courses have benefited the students?

    The Chairman: The answer is to ask the students!

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I am much obliged, Mr Speaker, Sir. When we formed the Government, one of the difficulties that faced us was that we inherited a civil service which, by and large, was incapable of making political judgment. Our local civil service, though technically competent, had always been under the illusion that because they should be non- political in character they must avoid all interest in political affairs to the extent of even being ignorant of political issues. For instance, the opinion has always been expressed that, as civil servants, they must not indulge or dabble in politics, as if politics is a kind of parlour game intended for the amusement or diversion of people. The way we look at it is that political affairs is not a parlour game. On the contrary, it may be a matter of life and death whether or not we can build up a democratic system of sufficient strength to withstand the stresses that our country has to meet. This is not such a simple matter as some Members of the Opposition may think. It is not sufficient just to say that the civil servants are there to carry

Column: 387

out the policies and instructions of Ministers. When they carry out policies, they necessarily must have a wide sphere of discretion. It is not possible for Ministers to give directives in detail to enable the civil servant to meet any possible eventuality. If the role of the civil service were just to carry out instructions in a mechanical way, that is, to be guided purely by the letter of the General Orders or by such circulars and directives as may be issued, you can be sure that the Government would not be able to make any impact upon the people. This lack of experience or lack of involvement or lack of thinking on the part of the civil servants on political issues has been detrimental to themselves, because they have not been able to see how they have been separated from the masses, why that is a bad thing and why it is necessary for them to know what the masses think about political affairs, their hopes and aspirations, so that the execution of Government policy can be made more effective.

    As regards the school principals, it is obvious, Sir, that they have a vital role to perform in the task of nation-building. They are the key persons who will mould the form and content of the thinking of the younger generation. And like the civil servants, the school principals have not given any thought to the political issues of the day, nor have they made any effort to understand the general political background not only, in respect of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya but also the general resurgence of nationalism in Asia in the post-war years. These are matters they must appreciate, and it is the purpose of the Political Study Centre to run courses of instruction for these groups of Government employees. As I have said, the effect on them has been very marked and immediate. I myself have gone to the Political Study Centre after sessions and held informal discussions with civil servants and school principals on what they thought of these courses; and apart from a few diehards who cannot understand what it is all about or who cannot appreciate the necessity for re-thinking of the basic issues, the general effect has

Column: 388

been, one might almost say, the reconversion to a new point of view of which they were completely unaware previously.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I entirely agree with the Minister that civil servants who have to carry out instructions cannot do so effectively unless they know the background to these instructions and the policies on which they are based. I would like to ask the Minister a question in connection with the studies and courses held in the Political Study Centre. I agree that the students attending these courses have become more knowledgeable men, but would the Minister state categorically that the knowledge they have gained have made them more efficient civil servants, and that the civil service has become a more efficient service?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I would say without a doubt that the answer is yes for this reason, quite apart from the content of the political instructions. The senior officers who went through these courses - many of them for the first time - understand now why Government policy is what it is, and they are therefore able to exercise their own initiative in promoting our policies instead of being jogged along by their Ministers. But I would be the last person to claim that what we have done is all that is necessary.

2.45 p.m.

    While the Political Study Centre has run courses for all Divisions I and II officers and a large number of school principals, we will in the next stage go through the other remaining principals of English schools and part of the Chinese school principals. We also intend to run more advanced courses for selected officers in Division I. As I have said, this is a continuing process, and I would say that the results we have achieved have justified our efforts in starting it.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I speak on the content of the courses that are made available at the Political Study Centre? While

Column: 389

agreeing with the Minister for Finance that it is a good thing for our civil servants to know what is going on around them, not only in Singapore but throughout the world, particularly in South-east Asia and Asia, and that it is good to educate them politically, the question that arises is this: whether the P.A.P. in power, while seeking to educate them, should itself, in the course of that political education, seek to gain an advantage. If the Party in power while politically educating the civil servants does not itself seek an advantage, I can see no objection to that. But I understand that some of the lecturers, tutors or whoever they may be, perhaps without the knowledge of the Minister, do adopt a line which quite blatantly praises the Party in power and quite openly runs down the other political Parties in Singapore. I wonder if the Minister for Finance knows this. If he knows this and he disagrees with it, will he stop it and give the Opposition an assurance that this will not continue to occur? Political education is a good thing, but to so educate the civil servants as to make them think that the P.A.P. is the only Party worth supporting, whether that is a thing to be done out of public funds is yet another matter.

    The other point, Sir, which I indicated to you could conveniently be dealt with this, is sub-head 63 on page 273 of the Estimates. Could the Minister for Finance tell the House what exactly would the Service Manual contain?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: As regards the statement that we might be taking party political advantage of this institution, I can assure the Member that that is very far from our intention. In fact, if we had attempted to make it, shall we say, an arm of the Party, then we would not have achieved the success that we did. Surely the civil servants could have seen through this. It could be, mind you, that in the process of discussing the particular issues the policy of the Government might have been examined, and it might have been demonstrated

Column: 390

very convincingly to the students that that was the correct and only policy that could be followed. In that instance, I would say that the lecturers were explaining the policy of the Government, as distinct from praising the excellence of the Party leadership. I know there is a subtle difference, but nevertheless it is there. As for running down the Opposition, if the Member for Farrer Park could give me details as to when that happened and who did it, I will assure him that steps will be taken to stop it. But I rather suspect that the Member for Farrer Park was either speaking with his tongue in his cheek, or he was badly misinformed.

    On the second point, that is, the Manual, it is nothing more than a booklet setting out the attractions of a career in the Civil Service. The previous Government published one in, I think, 1956. It is now out of date. We are revising this Manual, so that copies of it can be distributed to schools, colleges, and so on-places where we want to recruit civil servants.

    Mr Rajah: Sir, while I entirely agree with the Minister for Finance that the line is very difficult to draw, he will also agree with me that there are certain instances where one cannot but help think that that line is being taken. There could be cases where a line is difficult to draw. Yet there are other instances where one knows quite well that a certain line is being taken, not to put across a theory to the students, but merely to run down some previous Minister or ex-Minister, or something like that. If, in the course of putting across a theory, a discussion entailed the merits of a policy followed by a former Chief Minister and the present Prime Minister, that is all right. But where gratuitous insults are hurled at ex-Ministers or ex-Chief Ministers, then I think that is going a bit too far.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I was not raising this with my tongue in my cheek, but I have had it seriously mentioned to me that this was going on. And in fairness to the Minister, I felt I had to raise it.

Column: 391



    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I am obliged to the Member for drawing my attention to it, and I shall certainly see to it that if this thing had indeed occurred, it will not take place in future.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister tell us whether these courses are voluntary, or are civil servants told that they have to attend?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The courses for school principals are voluntary. The courses for civil servants are compulsory; they have to attend.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am one of the many Ministers who go to the Political Study Centre to give lectures, and to be lectured to. It is quite true that, by and large, we drew up the courses and we took great care to see that they were not primarily intended to put forward a party point of view, because that would have destroyed the purpose of the courses. For example, last Wednesday. I think, I had to go there and one of the questions often asked was: "Is it true that the P.A.P. is anti-English educated?" In reply to a question like that, I asked, "Why do you say so?" Then they quoted speeches made by certain political Parties. Naturally when we replied to such thing we said that that was a very stupid statement. I do not know whether that is taken as putting forward propaganda detrimental to a particular political Party. Very often we were asked, "Is it true that the P.A.P. is run by Communists?" And we replied. "Who said so?", and certain Members of the Opposition were quoted. And we said that that was a very stupid remark, in that sense, it could be. But by and large the purpose of these courses, apart from imparting instruction in political theories and so on, is to provide the Ministers with an opportunity to get ordinary members of the civil servants to be critical. Very often they are very critical of Government policy. They ask questions like "Why was it done this way?" or they say that they disagree with a particular policy, and we try to explain why we do these

Column: 392

things. To that extent, I think these courses serve a broader purpose apart from imparting political knowledge - they give civil servants an opportunity to discuss things with their Ministers; not only people at higher levels but in the intermediate levels as well. Therefore, they would then feel that they are not just dummies carrying out instructions by the Government. They feel they have a sense of participation; that their advice is listened to, and in a number of cases they have put forward very fruitful suggestions about how political problems should be approached, and so on. To that extent, these courses are of mutual advantage not only to the people who go there but also to the Ministers concerned.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, when I saw the Minister for Culture speaking there, I seemed to see the face of Professor Enright! Why I bring it up is this: this is the Political Study Centre to inject political thought into the civil servants. The Government says that such political activities cannot be indulged in by aliens. Yet the Director of this Political Study Centre is not a Singapore citizen. How does that reconcile with Government's policy?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The answer surely is very simple, Mr Speaker, Sir. The Director is an officer of the Government and he has duties and functions to perform in carrying out the policies of the Government.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, I think it is indeed very simple. So long as an alien plays the line of the P.A.P., it is simple. If he does not play the line of the P.A.P., it is no longer simple; he is brought to book.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, that remark is as foolish as it is offensive. There is no similarity at all between the role of an officer of the Government performing his functions in the office of the Government, and an academic man holding forth in public on matters of public policy. The work of the Director of the Political Study Centre is within the closed walls of the Civil Service.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Professor Enright's lecture-

Column: 393



    The Chairman: Order. I do not think we need bring in Professor Enright in this connection at all.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: This is just to show, Sir, that so long as any alien is prepared to play the line of the P.A.P., it is quite all right to the Government.

    The Chairman: Order. I think that question has been answered. It is becoming a little tedious.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Hon. the Minister for Finance whether this teacher who is teaching political science in the Political Study Centre is allowed to use his own discretion and participate in it? If he has ideas that are adverse to Government policy, will he still be employed? Will he be brought to book if he teaches what is fact in the history of politics, and in certain Government policies he happens to disagree with them and condemn them?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: That question, I think, is out of order because it is purely hypothetical.

    The Chairman: I think the Minister should leave it to the Chair to decide what is or what is not out of order. In the Committee of Supply, arguments are always hypothetical, or most of them are.

    Is the Member for Mountbatten asking for a vote on this?

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, in view of the explanation given, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

*The same admendment stood in the names of Tun Lim Yew Hock and Mrs Seow Peck Leng.


    Sub-head 10, Mr Speaker, Sir, is in connection with expenses in connection with travelling on Government duty. In this year's Estimates, there is a sum of $100,000, and in next year's Estimates, it is intended to double it - more than

Column: 394

double, I am reminded. Could the Minister please explain whether Government is going to travel twice as much as it has done this year?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The Government expects to travel as much next year as this year.

    Mr Rajah: In that case, the vote should not exceed $100,000. That was the point of my objection. As the vote now is $100,000, and it is intended to be increased to $206,000 for next year, have the fares gone up twice as much then for the same amount of travel?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, actually the vote of $100 000 for this year has now been exhausted, and it has been necessary to replenish it by transfers from other heads. I do not know whether we are going to embark upon a long argument about travelling abroad. But it became quite obvious in the course of this year that we had many conferences and meetings to attend abroad. As far as possible, it is the practice of this Government to send officials and unofficials on conferences overseas. I have before me a figure of nearly 90 persons who have travelled abroad on various Government conferences and meetings. Of these 90 persons, only five are Ministers. I do hope that by providing this explanation the Opposition will not waste the time of the House in irrelevant debate.

    The Chairman: Order -

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I mean in unnecessary debate.

    The Chairman: The Minister appears to be taking unto himself the functions of the Chair.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, one can understand the feelings of the Minister when an embarrassing question is asked. It is indeed a very embarrassing question, Sir, particularly as we know that, with regard to this travelling overseas, it has been the practice of P.A.P. Ministers and P.A.P. supporters and Assemblymen to go round telling these unofficial people, who are being allowed to travel

Column: 395

overseas, that if they will just join the P.A.P., they could have a trip overseas. If the Minister will just give the names of the 90 persons who have gone overseas, I can assure this House that 90 per cent of them are P.A.P. members.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I am afraid the Member for Cairnhill is acquiring some of the bad habits of the Member for Hong Lim. The facts are quite the reverse. The majority of the persons who have gone abroad are officials.

    The Chairman: Unless the Member wishes to debate on the principle of Government travelling, these details, as I have suggested before, could well be looked into by the Estimates Committee; and if the Estimates Committee finds that the expenses are too extravagant, it will probably report back to the Assembly. If the Member wishes to attack the principle, by all means do so.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: With respect. Sir, it is on the question of principle. Public Funds are being spent to send P.A.P. members overseas. If the Hon, the Minister will give the names of those persons, apart from officials and Ministers, the public will surely have their eyes opened as to who have been travelling on public funds.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Cairnhill is really being quite tiresome about this. I would say straightaway that the number of Ministers who have gone abroad - and I am the one who has gone more than any of my colleagues - is much less than that under his Government. It is quite untrue to say that any public funds have been wasted by sending members of the People's Action Party abroad. When a Party is in government, it is natural that the Ministers and some of the Parliamentary Secretaries would be sent abroad to conferences as representatives of the Government. May I suggest, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the debate is getting quite tedious unnecessarily, and that the procedure would be for the Estimates Committee to satisfy itself whether there has been any gross abuse of public funds in this year's expenditure?

Column: 396



    The Chairman: The Minister, as I have remarked before, would like to be in this Chair himself! I can assure him that I am watching the point very carefully. There seems to be a difficulty in drawing the line between principles and details in this particular matter. But perhaps we could deal with the matter with less excitement.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid the Minister is evading the issue. I have said "unofficials". By "unofficials" I mean pot Government servants, not P.A.P. Ministers and not P.A.P. Assemblymen, but those who are not in this Assembly and those who are not in the service of the Government. If the Minister will not give us a list of those names, I can now understand why he is evading the issue.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, if that is the question he asks, then I say that no member of the P.A.P. has been sent abroad at Government expense as a member of the P.A.P.

    Mr Rajah: May I beg leave to withdraw, Sir?

I see that a similar item appears at page 287, under Customs and Excise, sub-head 15 - "Refund of Previous Years' Revenue". Could the Minister please explain whether it is for accounting purposes that the refund is made? I take it that these were revenues which were intended to be collected in the year 1960, but will be collected in 1961, and, therefore, are refundable to the 1960 account. Is that the position?

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 28 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 49.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, this sum of $2,000,000 appears as a charge against the Consolidated Fund, whereas, in point of fact, it is, I take it, an advance to the City Engineer's Department to enable them to make purchases of materials, stores, spares, etc. As this $2 million has the effect of creating a deficit or adding to the expenditure of Government, could I ask the Minister whether there is a corresponding entry somewhere on the revenue side in respect of this $2 million?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is one of the tricky operations we have to go through on account of the integration of the City Council into the Government. Perhaps I should explain how the Advance Account works. The Member for Farrer Park probably has some knowledge of this subject. The City Council accounts are operated on an accrual basis, that is, an income and expenditure basis, so that debits and credits are made into the votes as and when the operation takes place. For instance, in the case of the City Engineer's Department, they buy stocks of sand, granite, tyres, petrol and so on, and the costs of these things are charged to an advance account. As and when particular departments want these materials, be it the Sewerage Department or the City Transport Centre, these materials are supplied by the City Engineer and the vote of the department using these materials is debited. In the case of the Government, of course, it is different, because it works on a cash basis. The whole of the costs of any purchases would be debited against the vote of the buying department. The reason why we have decided to continue this Advance Account is that a change of procedure in the book-keeping involved would be a fairly formidable undertaking, and this is one of the compromises referred to in my speech and

Column: 398

in the memorandum whereby the accounting procedures of the City Council have been maintained, at least for this year. By next year we hope that the accounting system would be on the Government basis. I hope this explanation is clear to the Member for Farrer Park.

    Mr Rajah: As I understand it, Mr Speaker, Sir, this is because of budgeting purposes and is really an artificial deficit to the extent of $2 million. On that basis, may I have leave to withdraw?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 28 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 50.

    Sir, I take it that this is an item of expenditure which the Singapore Government is incurring in respect of trainees coming into Singapore and whom we are assisting in training under the Colombo Plan. May I also deal with sub-head 52, Sir? I think it would be convenient if it were to be dealt with at the same time.

    The Chairman: Yes.

    Mr Rajah: Sub-head 52 is Colombo Plan Technical Assistance, Local Costs. How is that related then to sub-head 50?

    The Chairman: The Question is, "That the sum to be allocated for Head 28 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 50." The debate may range over sub-head 52.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sub-head 50, Mr Speaker, is as the Member for Farrer Park has indicated. That is, we have made offers to all Colombo Plan countries for training facilities in very extensive fields in Singapore ranging from courses in engineering, architecture, accountancy at the Polytechnic, to health visitors' and public health inspectors' courses by the Ministry of Health, practical training in low-cost housing by the Housing Board, training in port management by the Singapore Harbour Board, and courses in telecommunications, civil aviation and so on

Column: 399

and so forth. This vote is to provide for the cost of allowances as scholarships for the trainees in Singapore as well as for transport allowances, books, equipment and tuition fees where applicable. The other one, that is the Colombo Plan Technical Assistance, Local Costs, is to pay for experts sent to Singapore under the Colombo Plan. Under the scheme, the donor countries will pay the cost of the salaries and passages of these experts, but we will have to meet the local costs, such as the cost of board and lodging if they are staying for a short while, or a fixed allowance of $600 per month plus a transport allowance of $7.50 if they are staying longer. We have now some 20 Colombo Plan experts assisting the Government at the present moment.

    Mr Rajah: In view of that explanation, Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have leave to withdraw?

    Sub-head 68 is Singapore Industrial Promotion Board. Mr Speaker, Sir, during the debate on the Estimates for

Column: 400

the year 1960, I had occasion to refer to this particular item and I did suggest to the Minister then that perhaps no useful purpose could be served by this. Over the year I have waited to see what this Industrial Promotion Board is doing to Singapore. It may be doing something on paper, but the people certainly do not know of it. So far as the actual achievements of the Singapore Industrial Promotion Board are concerned, Singapore has not seen any concrete results yet. Perhaps the Minister could tell us what the Board has achieved during the current year and what it hopes to achieve in the forthcoming year, particularly when I see that he has allocated a sum of $20 million to the Economic Development vote.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I did say last year that the Industrial Promotion Board is in the process of being wound up.
